item.title: Suspected of sending drones to North Korea worked in former South leader's office
item.description: Two civilians suspected of being involved in recent drone deployments to North Korea worked in former President Yoon Suk-yeol's office, according to an investigation published yesterday by local news agency Yonhap. The news was released at a time when an investigation is being carried out in Seoul in response to Pyongyang's accusations about the presence of drones in North Korea, in September 2025 and at the beginning of this year. The first suspect, a man in his 30s, who apparently only worked on manufacturing the drone, was a news supervisor in the presidential spokesperson's office during the Yoon government, according to the agency. The other suspect, also in his 30s and also working at the presidential complex during the Yoon government, publicly claimed to have operated the drones, in an interview broadcast on Friday by local channel Channel A. The suspect is currently pursuing postgraduate studies in journalism at a private university in Seoul. The two suspects studied at the same university and founded a drone manufacturing company in 2024, according to Yonhap. The investigation does not specify the exact years they worked for Yoon, who began his term in May 2022 and ended in April last year, after being removed by the brief declaration of martial law in December 2024. Yoon Suk-yeol, currently in pre-trial detention, faces charges of abuse of power and other crimes related to the alleged sending of drones to North Korea to disseminate anti-Pyongyang propaganda. The Public Ministry alleges that the then president ordered the operation to provoke a reaction from the neighboring country and justify the imposition of martial law. Flights of discord North Korea accused the South at the UN, in February last year, of sending drones in October 2024 to spread propaganda over the capital Pyongyang. Yonhap's work also indicates that the first suspect was already interrogated on Friday by the investigation team of the South Korean armed forces and police. The man was reported to the authorities in November for flying an unregistered drone in the Yeoju area, about 70 kilometers southeast of Seoul, and the model of the device coincided with the one North Korea claims to have shot down in the most recent report. In an interview with a local channel, the second suspect said that, since September last year, he had carried out several flights over North Korea and that the objective was to measure the levels of radiation and contamination by heavy metals in a uranium factory near the Ryesong River, in North Korean territory. North Korea reported on January 10 that South Korean drones flew over the territory in September last year and again on January 4 this year. The government of the current South Korean President, Lee Jae-myung, denied that the drones were military aircraft and began an investigation this week, without ruling out the possibility of civilian involvement. The North Korean accusation came as a surprise, given that Lee had told the EFE news agency in December that Seoul might have to apologize to Pyongyang for alleged drone flights during Yoon's presidency.

item.title: Health | Meeting brings together authorities from Macau, Hong Kong and Mainland China
item.description: Last Thursday, the MSAR hosted the 20th Joint Meeting of the Health Administration Summits of Mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, where the training of qualified staff, community health and the development of intelligent healthcare were discussed. The meeting brought together more than 70 senior health administration officials and medical experts from the three territories also with the objectives of “deepening the exchange, sharing of experiences and discussion on the future direction of cooperation”, the Health Services indicated on Friday. The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, highlighted that the Macao SAR Government will implement the strategy of giving “health priority” included in the “National Fifteenth Five-Year Plan” and execute the “Action Plan for Healthy Macau”, integrating physical and mental health elements into public policies. The leader also highlighted the launch of the “Well-being and Health Station” program, to take advantage of health resources in community neighborhoods. Complying with the national “Year of Weight Management” initiative, O Lam stated that “community health self-examination stations will be increased” and residents will be encouraged to “be ‘first responsible’ for their own health”.

item.title: New association wants to contribute to the study of law in Macau
item.description: The Association of Legal Studies of Macau and Portugal was created to give life to a mega undertaking, the publication of the annotated Macau Civil Procedure Code, and, later, of works “outside the most popular topics”. David Sá Machado, a Portuguese lawyer working in Macau, is the ideologue of what will be the first annotated version, published in full, of the Civil Procedure Code of the semi-autonomous Chinese region. The three volumes, with the contribution of around 60 authors, including “lawyers, magistrates, academic professors, advisors and other jurists from Portugal and Macau”, should see the light of day later this year, the person responsible explains to Lusa, noting that they are in the review phase. “If there are changes to the code planned, we may delay a little”, he adds. To facilitate the publication of the work, “an added value” that aims to be a “contribution to law in Macau”, the Association of Legal Studies of Macau and Portugal was created. “Other projects will emerge later”, says Lusa Sá Machado, president of the association, indicating the intention of, in the future, organizing “more pedagogical and more didactic initiatives”. Still talking about this project of around three thousand pages and coordinated by two women – Maria José Capelo, associate professor at the Faculty of Law at the University of Coimbra, and Teresa Leong, retired judge from Macau – the lawyer notes that it will be produced in Portuguese, although a Chinese version is also planned, as “the target audience is jurists from Macau”. “An annotated code should serve to clarify the reader of the various interpretative meanings of the norms and, perhaps, add something from the point of view of the right to be constituted”, he indicates. “I think it always enriches any legal system”, he adds Existing versions Macau has annotated versions of the Civil Code, the Penal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, and between 2006 and 2008, the first two volumes of the annotated and commented Code of Civil Procedure were published, authored by Cândida da Silva Antunes Pires and Viriato de Lima. The work, however, remained unfinished, recalls the lawyer. Sá Machado, also one of the authors, defends the importance of the project: "We are always using Portuguese codes, Portuguese notes. We are left with something of our own." Still talking about the work, which will be published in Portugal by Edições Almedina – after making “some approaches in Macau, informally” -, the lawyer says that “I would like it to be a reference work”.

item.title: Two more shows with Japanese artists canceled
item.description: The shows by the boy band Nexz, made up of Japanese and Korean artists, were canceled on Friday, without any official explanation, according to a statement from concessionaire Sands China. The two concerts were scheduled for Saturday and Sunday and were sold out. Initially, the band managed by JYP, one of the main Korean entertainment companies, had only planned one concert in Macau. However, the great demand, as early as December, led to a second show being scheduled the following day. On Friday, one day before the first concert, the cancellation occurred. “We inform you that the concert “NEXZ SPECIAL CONCERT in MACAO”, originally scheduled for the 17th and 18th of January 2026, has been cancelled”, announced the concessionaire, via social media. “We sincerely apologize for any inconvenience caused and thank you for your understanding and continued support,” it added. Shows with the participation of Japanese artists in Macau began to be canceled, after a worsening of diplomatic tensions between Japan and China related to Taiwan. Cancel culture The wave of cancellation of shows with Japanese artists in China began in the interior. However, the trend extended to Macau. The first target in Macao was pop singer Ayumi Hamasaki, whose concert, scheduled for January 10th, was canceled on December 9th. Days earlier, on November 29, Hamasaki's concert in Shanghai had also been cancelled. The cancellations didn't stop there, and at the beginning of the year it was time for Japanese singer Mika Nakashima's concert to be cancelled. At the time, the existence of “unavoidable circumstances” was presented as justification. The cancellation of shows is not new. In January 2024, pressure from the IC led to the cancellation of the “Made by Beauty” show due to the participation of drag queens. However, IC president Deland Leong denied any involvement in the spate of recent cancellations.

item.title: Diplomacy | “Healthy and stable” relations serve the interests of China and Canada
item.description: The Canadian government leader's visit to China marked the return of healthy understanding between the two nations after a period of tensions and disagreements. The President of China, Xi Jinping, stated Friday that the development of “healthy and stable” relations with Canada serves the interests of both countries, during a meeting with the Canadian Prime Minister. Xi met in Beijing with Mark Carney, in what is the first visit by a Canadian head of government to the country in almost a decade and which aims to normalize bilateral relations, which have gone through periods of tension in recent years, due to diplomatic and commercial disputes. During the meeting, held at the Great Hall of the People, Xi stated that the “healthy and stable development” of relations between China and Canada “corresponds to the common interests of both countries” and contributes to “world peace, stability and prosperity”, according to Chinese state television CCTV. The Chinese leader highlighted that the previous contact between the two, in October, on the sidelines of a summit in South Korea, began a new phase of rapprochement. Xi called for the construction of “a new type of strategic partnership” capable of putting ties between Beijing and Ottawa on a “sustainable and lasting” path. Carney thanked the reception and expressed Canada's willingness to work with China “based on good past cooperation”, to develop a strategic relationship adapted to the current international context and promoting “stability, security and prosperity” for both countries and the Pacific region. The day before, the Canadian Prime Minister met with his Chinese counterpart, Li Qiang. The two discussed topics such as economic cooperation, energy and trade, and witnessed the signing of several agreements in the customs and commercial areas. Reinforced ties According to CCTV, Carney reiterated Canada's interest in strengthening cooperation in supply chains and strategic sectors, as well as its commitment to multilateralism and the international trade system. Li Qiang advocated expanding cooperation in areas such as clean energy, modern agriculture, digital technologies and the aerospace industry. Also on the sidelines of the visit, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi met with Canadian Foreign Minister Anita Anand, highlighting the need to eliminate interference and strengthen mutual trust to promote a “stable, solid and healthy” relationship. Carney's visit is the first by a Canadian prime minister to China since Justin Trudeau's visit in 2017, and takes place in a context of growing instability in international trade, with Ottawa seeking to diversify economic partnerships.

item.title: CCM | Play “Goodbye, My Concubine” with workshops and activities
item.description: Between January 29th and February 1st, the Beijing People's Theater company presents four sessions of the play “Adeus, Minha Concubina” at Studio II of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM). Tickets cost 220 patacas and are on sale at the Enjoy Macao Ticket Office. Spectators can enjoy a 50 percent discount, “upon presentation of a valid Macau Resident Identity Card, Full-time Student Card, Macau Teacher Card, Special Benefits Card for the Elderly or Disability Assessment Registration Card”, said the Cultural Affairs Bureau on Friday. The performance of the play presented by the Beijing People's Theater is one of the highlights of the “1st Season of Chinese Culture Shows”, which began at the end of November last year and runs until March. The cycle is organized by the IC and the Publicity, Culture and Sports Department of the Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Macao SAR, with the sponsorship of the Secretariat for Social Affairs and Culture. The play, described by the organization as immersive, was written by Mo Yan, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature. The IC adds that the production of “Goodbye, My Concubine” that will take the CCM stage “breaks with the traditional narrative structure of historical drama, exploring timeless themes such as power, survival and responsibility through multiple encounters and a structure of temporally intertwined dialogues between the characters Yu Ji and Lü Zhi”. With an immersive scenic design, the audience will be surrounded by the Chu Army camp, sitting on cushions or straw benches arranged on various levels, to witness up close the intense plots of love and hate between the characters. Learning with art In addition to the four theater sessions, “workshops and complementary activities will also be organized that invite the public to participate and experience the beauty of traditional Chinese culture from multiple perspectives”, is described by IC. On the 30th and 31st of January, after the show (between 10pm and 10:30pm), spectators will have the opportunity to talk to the artists. On January 27th, in anticipation, the “Inter-regional Dialogue between Young Artists” will be organized, which will feature “the main creators of the production and young actors from Mainland China and Macau”. The objective of this activity is to launch an “in-depth discussion about the construction of characters and the performing arts, deconstructing the creative process, perceptions and techniques for representing dramatic characters from multiple dimensions, such as action, personality and image”. The talk, scheduled for the Auditorium of the Macau Art Museum, is aimed at theater groups and young actors based in Macau and admission will be on a first-come, first-served basis. In addition to the conversations, an enamel jewelry workshop will be held on January 31st between 4:30 pm and 5:30 pm in the Conference Room of the Macau Cultural Center, aimed at Macau residents over 6 years old The next day, in the same place and at the same time, the Calligraphy Workshop for the Elderly will be held for Macau residents over 55 years of age. Places are limited and interested parties can register on the Macau Single Account application.

item.title: Birth rate | Equality and balance between essential work and life
item.description: A UPM academic believes that Macau should legislate equal parental leave, promoting gender equality and balance between personal life and work, which she claims are essential factors in reversing the drop in birth rates. “The balance between professional and personal life is a key factor in boosting the fertility rate,” Lok Cheng, an academic at the Macau Polytechnic University (UPM) who studies public policy, told Lusa. Lok's research, which compares Macau's parenting policies with those of countries such as Germany, Sweden and the United States, supports this conclusion. Macau recorded the lowest birth rate in the world in 2024 and the lowest number of births in almost 50 years in 2025, said, at the beginning of the year, the deputy director of the Macau public hospital, Tai Wa Hou, quoted by the Chinese language channel of the public broadcaster TDM Macau. This decline has persisted despite a revised budget approved last year to strengthen social supports, including subsidies for parents with children up to three years old, increases in birth benefits and marriage subsidies. Macau currently offers 70 days of maternity leave and only five days of paternity leave for workers in the private sector (in the public sector it is 90 days for mothers and five for fathers), recalled the expert: “Less than the 98 days recommended by the International Labor Organization”, she said. This disparity, argued Lok, reinforces the idea that women have the main responsibility for newborns, which also has an impact on their professional career. “We have tacitly accepted that women have a greater responsibility for caring for newborns, and this is reflected in the workplace,” he continued. Look out In contrast, the expert, who is also a civil servant, points to European policies. “Sweden has a well-established parental policy and saw an increase in the birth rate in the early 2000s,” he said. “Both Germany and Sweden provide longer maternity leaves and are actively promoting father participation”, he reinforced. Lok explained that Sweden offers more than 300 days of shared parental leave, with 90 days reserved exclusively for the father. “Macau currently has no relevant regulations regarding fathers”, noted the academic, suggesting that the region could learn from this model to implement equal parental leave and “promote gender equality in the workplace”. Such a policy, he said, would help families share childcare and “eliminate gender bias that places women as the main caregivers”. “This prejudice is harmful to women’s professional development”, he assessed. According to the latest official data from the Macau Women's Database, the average monthly salary of the female population in 2024 was 16,800 patacas, lower than the 19,300 patacas earned by men. Lok explained that many women are hesitant to have children, fearing increased family duties and career stagnation. But when childcare is shared, “this can increase the desire to have children and reduce the associated costs”. Such a change would also benefit women professionally, he added. If parental duties were distributed more equally, “companies would be less concerned about gender when hiring women of childbearing age, and women would be able to pursue careers on an equal footing.” Lok acknowledged that it may be a challenge for Macau to adopt a system like Sweden's, but it is necessary to “move forward gradually”. “The first step is to increase maternity leave to 98 days, in accordance with international standards”, he concluded.

item.title: Game | VIP revenues rose 24.1% throughout 2025
item.description: Revenues from high rollers, a segment known in Macau as VIP gaming, rose 24.1 percent in 2025, according to official data released on Friday. The VIP baccarat game reached revenues of MOP68 billion last year, revealed the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Department (DICJ). In the last quarter alone, revenue from big bets increased by 45 percent compared to the period between October and December 2024, to 20.3 billion patacas. However, VIP gaming in Macau remains far from the historic peaks reached before the Covid-19 pandemic. In 2019, baccarat for this segment represented 46.2 percent of total casino revenues. But in 2025 it was left with a share of 27.5 percent. Big bets were affected by the arrest of the leader of the largest VIP bet collecting company in the world, in November 2021. The former executive director of Suncity Alvin Chau Cheok Wa was sentenced, in January 2023, to 18 years in prison, in a case that saw the number of gambling promoter licenses issued in Macau drop from 85 to 18. According to data from DICJ, the number of licenses has been recovering and reached the mark of 30 at the end of July, a number that was maintained in the most recent update, on December 15th. Even so, it remains below the maximum limit set by the Government, which is 50. Number to increase Revenues from the most popular game in Macau, baccarat in the so-called mass market, also increased by 3.4 percent in 2025, to 137.9 billion patacas. Mass baccarat represented 57.7 percent of total casino revenue in the territory last year, being by far the most popular game of chance among Chinese gamblers. Gaming machine revenue increased by 7.3 percent compared to 2024, to MOP13.9 billion. In 2025, Macau's casinos recorded total revenue of 247.4 billion patacas, an increase of 9.1 percent. The Macau Government had forecast, in the initial budget for 2025, gaming revenue of 240 billion patacas, which would represent an increase of 6 percent compared to the previous year. However, on June 11, the Legislative Assembly approved a new budget, proposed by the Executive, which reduced the forecast for public revenue by 4.56 billion patacas. The Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip, admitted to deputies that the cut was due to the fact that the game's gross revenues in the first quarter of 2025 were “slightly below expectations”.

item.title: Elections | Portuguese in Macau ask for attention from those far away
item.description: Outside the historic building of the Consulate General of Portugal in Macau, Portuguese people who chose to vote on Saturday celebrate the democratic moment and demand “more care” for those who live far away. Several voters again suggested the implementation of electronic voting. It was a “somewhat confusing - as the world is at the moment -” presidential campaign, but one that Cristina Osswald made a point of following. And on this sunny, winter day in Macau, the Portuguese celebrate the possibility of choice. "Whenever possible I would listen to interviews, debates and presentations of the candidates. But it seemed to me that, perhaps, there is this issue of a dispersion of votes, which is part of democracy, isn't it? And especially when you live in a regime that is not democratic, you clearly appreciate democracy more", the professor at the Macau Polytechnic University tells Lusa after voting. But the path that a Macau voter takes until the moment of voting, highlights Osswald, is not ideal. Having lived outside of Portugal for six years, the teacher notes that “procedures have improved”, although “they remain below expectations”. “The world is increasingly global, I see no reason why there should not be electronic voting”, considers the teacher, who, before Macau, passed through Florence, where to vote she had to go to Milan. “We can go to the bank [‘online’], to the finance department, and not being able to vote ‘online’ seems like something that doesn’t make much sense. I think that would be where there should also be greater investment. For example, here, people with little mobility cannot come and vote”, she declares. Cristina Osswald looks at the staircase that leads to the consulate, where at that moment, elderly people are climbing the steps with difficulty – despite the fact that, at the back of the building, there is another door with access to an elevator. "It is democracy that is losing. In times that are complicated and, I would say, almost dramatic, I think it would be an extremely simple thing to be able to vote online", continues the professor, also referring to the "little information" in Macau about the procedures leading up to the election. “I know a lot of people here in Macau, especially older people, who don't come to vote, because it wasn't announced that we had to register beforehand”, he notes. Ancient pretension Electronic choice has been a long-standing demand of the Council of Portuguese Communities, the Government's advisory body for policies relating to emigration and Portuguese communities abroad. Rui Marcelo, president of the Regional Council of the Portuguese Communities of Asia and Oceania, told Lusa last year that the topic “was addressed several times and with several governments”. Félix Teixeira, a retired laboratory technician who has lived in Macau for 30 years, argues that online voting could serve especially regions where “travel is difficult”. “Macau is small, it doesn’t matter here.” And what expectations do you have from the presidential elections? For the former employee of the Institute for Municipal Affairs, the multiplicity of faces on the bulletins is a good omen: “More voices are heard”, he says. And for emigrants, he emphasizes, being here today means getting closer to home: “If you are not in direct contact with the country, you are outside the entire circuit, politics and the social sphere”, he adds. Feel from a distance According to the consulate, there are more than 150 thousand Portuguese passport holders among residents of Macau and Hong Kong. However, when registered to vote, the number is almost three times lower: 57,748, according to data provided to Lusa by the diplomatic representation. From the top of the stairs of the historic consulate building – formerly Hospital de São Rafael, founded in 1569 – the Macanese couple Francisco Xavier Leong and Alina da Luz ask for more attention from those abroad. “We hope that the new president will be more careful with foreign citizens, not just from Portugal”, says Leong. “We vote because we are Portuguese and, as good citizens, it is our duty”, adds the woman. For the couple, who live nearby, voting in person is simpler. Francisco Leong even admits “more difficulty” with the electronic option. "Fortunately, in Portugal we have always had great confidence in the electoral results. There are many people who have doubts about electronic voting, but I think that if it is conducted well, it is a good option", says, in turn, José Paulo Esperança. To Lusa, the Finance professor at the City University of Macau says he expects high participation in the ballot, because “there are concerns for Portuguese democracy” and “worrying candidates”. "Portugal – and the world – is experiencing developments that worry me. Because there is an increasing rise in the extreme right and phenomena that are very worrying", he states. In the 2021 presidential elections, 1,479 people voted in Macau, or 2.1 percent of the total registered (70,134). Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa won in this Chinese region with 64.62 percent of the votes, followed by Ana Gomes (14.45 percent) and André Ventura (8.03 percent).

item.title: Government | Sam Hou Fai talks about “good start” to his term
item.description: The Chief Executive considers that the Government has made “a good start”. It was in this way that Sam Hou Fai took stock of the first year of governance, in a meeting with 70 members of the Administration to reiterate the need for rulers to “implement the spirit” of Xi Jinping's speeches. According to the official version of the meeting, released by the Social Communication Office, Sam Hou Fai “stated that the work of the first year of this government took place in a stable, successive and peaceful manner, with reforms, innovations, advances and results”, which he considered to be “a good start”. The Chief Executive praised public services for having as a priority “the fundamental interests of the Country and the integral interests of Macau” which are seen as “the starting point for installing a global mentality that firmly guarantees the sovereignty, national security and development interests of the Country, and ensures the stable and harmonious situation of Macau”. Secondly, Sam highlighted the efforts of employees to strengthen “interdepartmental collaboration and cooperation in order to increase executive efficiency” and highlighted the “precise” implementation of government actions. Sam Hou Fai also referred to “the importance of being more aware of shortcomings” and the need for shortcomings “to be checked as the work is carried out, in order to analyze existing problems and make appropriate improvements”. Follow the spirit Regarding the current year, Sam Hou Fai promised that he will continue “to fully implement the spirit of President Xi Jinping's speeches to plan future work”. The Government leader also called for a single-minded Government, which maximizes the “central role of the Chief Executive”. “All guardianships and services must unify the same thinking, make every effort and collaborate proactively, with a high sense of responsibility and mission and thus create an enormous force to work and advance together, so that, together, they complete this priority task of the Macao SAR government for this year”, he stated. “At the same time, it must urge and improve the predominance of executive power, maximizing the central role of the Chief Executive and the Macao SAR government in the governance system,” he added. And in this organization centralized around the Chief of Executive, the Legislative Assembly is also included: “The Secretary for Administration and Justice must effectively fulfill her duties and responsibilities, reinforcing coordination and cooperation to ensure that the Macao SAR government assumes its central governance functions with professionalism and pragmatism, in order to create a governance structure with an interconnection between the upper and lower levels and a synergy of cooperation between services, and to promote positive interaction between the executive powers and legislative bodies that cooperate, support and promote reciprocally, at an institutional, political and operational level”, he said.

The cancellations didn't stop there, and at the beginning of the year it was time for Japanese singer Mika Nakashima's concert to be cancelled. At the time, the existence of “unavoidable circumstances” was presented as justification. The cancellation of shows is not new. In January 2024, pressure from the IC led to the cancellation of the “Made by Beauty” show due to the participation of drag queens. However, IC president Deland Leong denied any involvement in the spate of recent cancellations.

item.title: FAM | IC welcomes proposals for new edition of the festival
item.description: The Cultural Institute (IC) is welcoming proposals for shows and initiatives that can be integrated into the 36th edition of the Macau Arts Festival (FAM), which takes place between May and June this year. According to a statement, the idea is to provide opportunities for artistic personalities and local organizations. “Over the years, FAM has sought to encourage the development of local arts and provide a quality platform for the presentation and exchange of performing arts in Macau”, describes the IC in a note. The aim of FAM is to “expand the exhibition platform for local performing arts and incorporate more creative works with local characteristics”. For this year's edition, the theme is “Cultural Encounter on the Maritime Silk Road”, inviting participants to “be inspired by Macau's unique cultural heritage”, to present works centered on the territory or “that incorporate specific elements of the city, such as historical architecture, notable figures, places and folk tales, exploring the city's distinct charm”. Proposals in the competition must fall into two categories, namely “Individual Programs”, which incorporate “all genres of shows, such as theater, Cantonese opera, dance, children's shows and multimedia performing arts”. In this category, the IC encourages “innovation and creative advances in artistic creation”. In turn, the second category, “Outdoor Showcase” consists of a “popular community program that seeks outdoor performances for the whole family and in a variety of formats”. The programs selected by IC will receive financial support to cover production costs. Interested local associations and individuals must register by February 10th. Candidates approved in the first selection phase must attend an interview with the jury that same month.

item.title: Thailand | New crane collapse leaves two dead and one injured
item.description: Two people died and one was injured after a crane fell onto a road on the outskirts of Thailand's capital, a day after a similar incident that killed at least 32 people. “Two people died and one was injured,” police officer Saranyapong Aonsingh told EFE news agency, adding that security officers were at the scene of the accident, where a viaduct was being built. According to reports from the Thai rescue and fire services on the social network Facebook, the crane collapsed at around 9:15 am, for reasons still unknown, at a construction site on the Rama II highway, in the province of Samut Sakhon, on the outskirts of Bangkok, hitting two cars. This accident happened one day after another crane fell on a passenger train, with 171 people on board, in northeastern Thailand, causing at least 32 deaths and more than 50 injuries. In both cases, the projects were linked to the local company Italian-Thai Development, according to Thai Transport Minister, Phiphat Ratchakitprakarn, in a television interview today. “We don’t know exactly what happened to the company (…). If the situation continues, we may have to announce a temporary stop of all its operations across the country”, he added.

item.title: One Oasis | Request for postponement of entry into force of new law
item.description: The One Oasis housing complex condominium will contact the administration to try to postpone the entry into force of the new law that prohibits hiring services from tourism agencies to transport residents of the building. The decision was taken on Friday, after a condominium meeting attended by more than 120 people, including representatives of public transport companies, and the solution aims to buy time to implement other measures. The controversy over the buildings' shuttle services arose after the Government proposed a law, unanimously approved by the Legislative Assembly last year, which clarified the type of services that can be provided by tourism agencies. As a consequence, the Executive promised a campaign against these agencies when they provide the shuttle bus service to residential buildings. In a statement, the Tourism Services Directorate also indicated that the law does not change anything, and that the ban already existed. The law change caught many residents off guard. Thursday's One Oasis condominium meeting aimed to seek a solution to the problem. The path thus involves hiring one of the only two companies that can now provide the service. Transmac charges 420 patacas for each bus trip, with a vehicle with 22 seats and 38 standing seats, an average of 7.1 patacas per person. TCM did not present a budget in time for the meeting. However, the condominium considered that it needs more time to apply the new model, and is seeking to obtain a postponement of the entry into force of the new law from the Government.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Jiang Shinian, also known as Shennong, the «Divine Farmer», patron saint of practitioners of traditional medicine (zhongyi), is also known as Yandi, the «emperor of flames» and is therefore able to control the «flaming wind», the excess heat that causes symptoms such as tremors, confusion or sudden fever. In religious practice, this “fire in the wind” is understood as the smoke that results from the burning of incense or papers that carry prayers, offerings or messages to the gods, ancestors or spirits up to the heavens. This fire, represented by the color red, is associated, among others, with immortality, positive energy forces or protection against evil. Shades of the color red were notoriously adopted by the emperors of the Ming dynasty who had Zhu, “vermilion or cinnabar” as their family name. One of the most publicly manifest examples was painting the walls of the “Forbidden Imperial City”, Zijincheng, purple, as a form of protection for the occupants inside, or giving the clothing of literate officials the color of cinnabar. When the dynasty fell and for many literati it became intolerable to obey the new emperors, some adopted the most diverse and subtle strategies of resistance. A scholar from the North who, in the plurality of his knowledge and vocations, came to use more than thirty names of brush, created for himself the name Zhuyi daoren, the «Daoist dressed in cinnabar» as if by using this protective color, he only recognized his own body as the only border or wall. In ordinary life, his name was Fu Shan (1607-1684), born in Yangqu, Shanxi, and from his refusal to serve his new masters, which harmed his day-to-day life, countless talents emerged, still celebrated today in two gardens in the city of Taiyuan, the provincial capital. And although all the literati who knew him recognized his qualities as a calligrapher, painter or poet, those closest to him saw him as a practitioner of traditional medicine, in particular as an expert on women's illnesses. Fu Shan preferred his handwriting to be “rough, not skillful; ugly, not seductive; deformed, not thin; spontaneous, not premeditated». And just like in paintings, he liked long vertical formats, as can be seen in a couplet in the Smithonian (ink on paper, 226 x 45.5 cm) where, reflecting his dual concern with the spirit and the body, he wrote: «If the spirit is calm, the mind naturally reaches the distance; The more relaxed your body is, the more of life you will be able to enjoy». He is credited with creating an “eight treasure soup”, made with eight ingredients that restored the most weakened. And yet, when he was forced to go to court in Beijing for the ritual of obedience to the new dynasty, he threw himself to the ground, suffering an incapacitating illness. Walking along the riverbank, enjoying the flowers, 6 (out of 7): Access to Huangsi's in-laws' house it is full of flowers everywhere, There are a thousand, ten thousand flowers pressing the branches, so full, bent. Repeatedly invite the butterflies to stay constantly dancing, I listen to orioles: how they are tuned in your delicate chirp. Du Fu (712-770)

The work, however, remained unfinished, recalls the lawyer. Sá Machado, also one of the authors, defends the importance of the project: "We are always using Portuguese codes, Portuguese notes. We are left with something of our own." Still talking about the work, which will be published in Portugal by Edições Almedina – after making “some approaches in Macau, informally” -, the lawyer says that “I would like it to be a reference work”.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: Ana Cristina Alves – Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center Simone Weil was born in Paris on February 3, 1909 and died on August 24, 1943, she lived little and intensely in a troubled time, crossed by two major world wars, the first between 1914 and 1918, and the second, between 1939 and 1945, particularly marked in her life. She was an outstanding French philosopher, of Jewish origin, teacher, politician and activist. Then he turned to mystical thought, leaving us with profound reflections on his relationship with God. He died at the age of 34 of heart failure while almost fasting, restricting his diet to a minimum, it is said, in a possible reading, by an occupied France in a gesture of solidarity with his compatriots who lived poorly and under the tutelage of the Nazis, while he was working for the French government in exile in Great Britain. He learned ancient Greek to speak in code with his older brother, mathematician André Weil, so that his parents could not understand them. Later he began studying Sanskrit, in order to be able to read Bhagavad Gita in the original and, at the time of his revolutionary furor, he was also a pacifist and trade unionist, concentrating his activity on literature classes for the working classes, as he considered that French literature was the right way to educate the workers' spirit and revolution in accordance with their cultural tradition. Later she visited anarchic thought, maintaining her pacifist vocation until she was confronted with the Nazi regime and the occupation of France. He reacted by joining the French Resistance, but he felt a strong spiritual call, so along with political activism, he developed a deep mysticism, despite having grown up in an agnostic environment. The call to the Christian faith began in 1935, in Portugal, having been touched by the beauty of our churches, while on vacation in Póvoa do Varzim. Later, in 1937, he felt religious ecstasy in Assisi in the small Romanesque chapel of Santa Maria degli Angeli, where Saint Francis used to pray. However, it is necessary to keep in mind that she was interested in several religious traditions that included the Greek and Egyptian mysteries, Hinduism, Mahayana Buddhism, among the religious experiences that culminated in her relationship not with Catholicism, but with Christianity, without ever advocating any type of religious syncretism. Let's move on to the presentation of the second thinker in this article, Byung-Chul Han, one of the best-known South Korean thinkers in the West, born in Seoul in 1959. He studied Metallurgy, later living in Germany, where he studied Philosophy at the University of Freiburg and German Literature and Theology at the University of Munich, currently teaching Philosophy at the University of Arts in Berlin. The philosopher brings us Conversations about God – A Dialogue with Simone Weil, in a 2025 publication, very well translated by Ana Falcão Bastos in Relógio D´Água Editores. His conversation with the philosopher Simone Weil develops around a reflection on God, combining his readings and interpretation of her thoughts, with him strongly heir to the Eastern immanentist tradition, which is why in the last chapter, entitled Inactivity, he fervently states: "Simone Weil imagines a kind of panpsychism. Everything is alive and animated. Without the spirituality of the universe, no relationship between it and the human spirit is possible" (Han, 2025, 81). According to his perspective, which he always believes he shares with Simone Weil, in order to talk to God an appropriate ethical stance is necessary, analyzed in the seven chapters into which he divides the work. It is then necessary to cultivate and accept Attention, Uncreation, Emptiness, Silence, Beauty, Pain and Inactivity. These are the right inner and outer ingredients to maintain a close relationship with God, who is not dead, as Nietzsche proclaimed, but rather very present to a humanity that does not seem to be capable of listening to or contemplating him. “It is not God who is dead, but the man to whom God revealed himself” (Han, 2025, 11), so we must cultivate the attention of the spirit, turn it towards God and this is done first and foremost with the teachings of Simone Weil: she died from the heart, in an exhausted, tubercular and bloodless body, or out of solidarity, or out of the belief that the less she ate, the more and better she would achieve union with God. Note the following reflection: "Two birds, inseparable companions, perch on the same tree. One eats the fruit from the tree, the other watches without eating." (Weil apud Han, 2025, 11). The world, according to both thinkers, is full of information, programs, and wrong attitudes, for example, binge watching, which means “devouring television programs”, in addition to all types of distractions, entertainment and food. Thus, it is advocated in the Buddhist or Taoist way, that it is necessary to be frugal, in a literal and metaphorical sense, to fast so that the soul triggers a process of “autophagy” leading to God, because “Only this autophagy of the soul saves and leads to God.” (Han, 2025, 12). In this way, the organism will eat its own meat, transforming it into energy. This practical philosophy taken to its ultimate consequences implies death, as happened to Simone Weil, when already very weakened, she saw her heart giving of itself. There is, however, a middle ground, which will need to be taken into account to develop the spirit's attention, as the spirit immersed in the flesh becomes incapable of concentrating. If absolute fasting is dangerous, as the Historical Buddha discovered sitting under the Ficus Religiosa, relative fasting, or rather dietary simplicity, can stimulate “contemplative attention” essential to seeing God. This vision requires deep attention, which can be used to solve a scientific or artistic problem, as in the God vision, because “God is attention without distraction” (Han, 2025, 14). Attention will thus be exercised in total concentration, similar to that used in prayer, in connection with the sacred, which is at the same time the supreme good, recalling the two forces of love and hate of the pre-Socratic philosopher Empedocles. These operate in the cosmos, making it organized, connected, attentive and loving, or disconnected, distracted and hateful. "Good unites and reconciles, while evil separates and divides. Evil is multifaceted. Good, on the contrary, is based on a single truth." (Han, 2025, 17). It is therefore natural to promote, within the framework of both thinkers, an “ethics of attention” or an ethics of mercy/compassion (Han, 2025,74), as only through this can a connection be achieved with others and, above all, with the Other, in an empathetic, spontaneous and deep connection. The way Byung-Chul Han defines Christian virtue is very interesting: “Christian virtue is not a search, it is not an action, but rather a waiting and observing (…) the role of the future wife is to wait” (Han, 2025, 18). I believe that, although it is an authorized reading of this virtue, the emphasis given to contemplative attention and waiting finds its reason for being within many Asian philosophies, which privilege non-action and even inactivity, as occurs in the seventh chapter of the work, being described in terms of the correct way of contact with the sacred, in an obedient, humble and silent posture. The author tells us, excluding the will, as much as possible: “It is inactivity that gives wings to the soul” (Han, 2025, 19) Perhaps for this reason, the first etymological definition of religion offered in the text refers to attention and the term religo means “relegere (reread)” (Han, 2025, 20). First of all, you need to know how to read the signs and pray or, in a more Eastern nomenclature, meditate. And continuing along this line that crosses East and West, to properly cultivate attention it is necessary to “empty” the soul to prepare it for connection to the sacred, which will allow us to introduce, in the last chapter, the second most common etymological definition in the West, “Religion as religare, means to connect, bind or unite” (Han, 2025,84) in a “reconnecting” what has been disconnected, the sacred and the profane in the style of Taoist and Buddhist philosophies. In this logic of thought of the South Korean philosopher, who talks to the French philosopher, emptiness is fundamental, not to give encouragement to life, as stated in the fourth chapter of the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经》), and remember: “the Tao is an empty vessel/it is used and never becomes full./unfathomable source of ten thousand things” (道冲而用之或不盈/渊兮似万物之宗)(Abreu, 2013,34-5), but, more in a Buddhist or Platonic way, to favor death. Cultivating emptiness is learning to be nothing, to uncreate oneself or lose the self, to renounce: “Empty means, ultimately, learning to die, surrendering oneself to death: «Praying is like death»” (Han, 2025,51). This reading, which is very indebted to Eastern tradition, is contrasted with an active Western Christian virtue, which finds God not in contemplative attention, although one can also be present there, but in active life, in relationships with others in the exercise of compassion or permanent love so that the kingdom of God descends as much as possible to earth. The definition of love advanced by Han, through Weil, is that of a “gaze of the soul”, that is, “love is based on the look as the attention of the soul.” (Han, 2025, 22). The cultivation of contemplation, waiting, silence and emptiness can lead to the presence of God, being a possible reading of the Sermon on the Mount, in which Jesus teaches that the lilies of the field and the birds of Heaven do not need to work or spin, God offers life as a gift and divine grace. However, if being is nothing, if obedience, silence and renunciation can lead to a theodynamics of love, care and attention must be taken that this is directed and concentrated on the relationship with God, because in human society an overwhelming thermodynamic of power dominates and according to the Western tradition we cannot run the risk of falling into the trap of power, because, as the author clearly sees, although he does not draw the ultimate consequences of what he writes: “Whoever has power has the feeling that they are growing spatially. It expands or extends. The increase in power manifests itself with an increase in the self” (Han, 2025, 42). The “re-connected” being will have to distinguish very carefully between the sacred and the profane, ensuring that their connection is true, or otherwise they will become a silent and renouncing nothing before their fellow man, which is absolutely intolerable for all the children of the same Father, as well as for the heirs of the Western philosophical tradition. Obviously, it is not advocating a thermodynamic power relationship, that is, full of energy and always expanding, that the author has in mind. Therefore, from a concrete and human point of view, it advises work relationships outside the master/slave connection, so denounced by Nietzsche in his attack on the Christian religion. In the mundane sphere, Han proposes that we escape either the labor relations created by industrial capitalist societies, in which “human beings are trained to become mechanical labor cattle” (Han, 2025,78), or by neoliberal performance societies in which people believe they are authentic and creative, but in reality embark on a productive frenzy in which they become “slaves of themselves” (Ibidem). So what seems to be the best solution for human beings in a world where work is fundamental? I confess that the author's response surprised and captivated me. The solution is to make work a loving theodynamic process, that is, not to carry it out without meaning, but to dedicate your actions to God, which for a Christian means, working out of love for others, carrying out a symbolic act, in the etymological sense of the term, as union and yet another way of penetrating the sacred sphere. Therefore, labor is poeticized, making it creative, in the manner of Simone Weil or Byung-Chul Han: "It is, therefore, about giving work a contemplative and spiritual character. Elevating it "to the highest point, that of the fullness of attention, which is the fullness of prayer." (Han, 2025, 85) Bibliographic References Abreu, António Graça de (trans.). 2013. Laozi.
