item.title: Study | Hong Kong society dominates depression news
item.description: A study published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research analyzed the themes and emotional tone of news stories about depression published in Hong Kong. The “societal system”, related to health, family or work, comes first with 34.83 percent of total news, having a “more negative inclination” The Hong Kong society system dominates the group of topics present in news about depression, representing 34.83 percent of the articles analyzed, followed by topics such as law enforcement, with 18.81 percent, or the global economic recession in third place. This is the main conclusion of the study “Analyzing Themes, Feelings, and Coping Strategies Regarding Online News Coverage of Depression in Hong Kong: Mixed Methods Study”, published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research last year. The study was authored by Chen Sihui, Cindy Sing and Yangna Hu, from Hong Kong Polytechnic University; and Cecília Cheng, from the University of Hong Kong. The study is focused on online news coverage about depression in the neighboring region, namely from publications such as the South China Morning Post and Hong Kong Free Press, and sought to understand the dominant themes and the emotional charge of the texts, whether they were positive or negative, among other issues. Thus, the study reveals that the region's “societal system” was at the origin of 34.83 percent of news about depression, that is, 848 out of a total of 2,435, followed by the theme of “law enforcement”, representing 458 of all news analyzed, with a share of 18.81 percent. This is followed, in third place, by the theme of “global recession”, with 17.4 percent of responses; “lifestyle”, with 8.05 percent; “leisure”, with 11.21 percent of responses; “health issues”, with 6.94 percent and, finally, “United States politics”, representing just 3.12 percent of the news. The study therefore describes that analyzing the sentiment inherent to the news, “it becomes evident that the societal system presented a more negative inclination”, being “related to several systems of Hong Kong society, including health, social, family, education and work”. Between extradition and covid-19 The collection of online news was carried out between February 2019 and May 2024 “with the aim of examining the most recent representation of depression, especially during and after the period of social unrest and the covid-19 pandemic”. The articles were chosen based on three criteria, one of which was accessibility to readers without a paid subscription, in addition to the fact that the website in question “should allow the retrieval of a sufficient quantity of depression-related news (i.e., more than 20) to ensure adequate data for subsequent analyses.” Websites with news in English were also chosen. Then, separate searches were carried out using the keywords “depression” and “depressed”. The dates chosen for this study relate to two events. One of them was in February 2019, with the introduction of the proposed law on extradition to China, entitled “Fugitive Offenders and Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation (Amendment)”. This “triggered protests and marches in Hong Kong due to political differences, leading to a significant increase in cases of depression, worsened in 2020 with the outbreak of Covid-19”. The authors reveal that there were “peaks in coverage” of news related to depression, namely in April and May 2020 and in July 2023. Covid-19 followed as a second occurrence. In the case of news from 2020, the study finds that “confinement measures due to covid-19 strongly affected Hong Kong, contributing to a more depressive mood”, and this period “corresponded to the second wave of the covid-19 outbreak”. The second pandemic wave led to strong confinement measures such as the closure of schools, “remote work policies and the ban on in-person meals in restaurants”. The closure of schools, “as reported in the news, resulted in increased rates of depression among children and anxiety among parents, who had to simultaneously care for their children and elderly people at home.” “In addition, conflicts between work and family also intensified due to the interruption of the normal work routine”, namely “the absence of office space and unclear working hours”, which “was associated with depressive feelings”, it is described. In turn, in 2023 there was an “increase in reported suicide cases”, especially because Coco Lee, “an influential star who faced depression, died by suicide at home, which generated greater awareness about the need to expand support services in the area of ​​mental health and improve accessibility, with helplines frequently being highlighted”. A certain stigma With regard to the second most common topic found in the news, “law enforcement”, the study highlights that it also causes “a negative feeling”. “The volume of news reached peaks in November 2020 and August 2019”, and in 2020, “individual crimes and legal proceedings were mainly reported, with emphasis on the case of a Hong Kong teacher who murdered his wife, which may have caused a great social shock and public attention”. The authors explain that, in this case, “depression was frequently cited in the news as an explanation for the perpetrator's illegal actions, which can reinforce stigmatizing attitudes and portray people with depression as violent, dangerous and more likely to commit crimes”. Other topics that also showed “negative trends” are “health issues” and “United States politics”, with topics such as “lifestyle” or “leisure” “tending towards more positive feelings”. With regard to another theme associated with news about depression, that of the “global recession”, the focus is the “economic difficulties caused by the spread of covid-19 in different sectors”, presenting “a more contradictory positive feeling”. In other words, “the structure of the reports initially described the economic challenges, to then emphasize the initiatives to facilitate recovery in response to the crisis”. Thus, the authors note that “a significant change in general sentiment was observed”, as “until January 2021, the continuous decrease in the amount of positive news was interrupted”, and that afterwards “the aggregate number of positive news exceeded that of negative news almost every month, signaling a general change from a negative feeling to a more positive feeling in relation to the economic circumstances discussed”. The authors consider that the change may be due “to the fact that people have been forced to adapt to a ‘new normal’ and begin the recovery of the economy, health, and society after a year of living with the pandemic”. Regarding the theme of US politics found in news associated with depression, the texts “emphasized rivalry and the presidential electoral process, as well as politicians from different parties who experienced depression”. Few institutional responses The study also looked at so-called coping strategies, that is, cognitive or behavioral efforts used to deal with less good situations. And here, the news analyzed focused mainly on “information about skills and resources” available to help people with depression, such as “support lines for suicidal intentions and suicide prevention”. Mental health programs provided by local organizations were also presented, such as Mind HK, the Kely Support Group and the Mental Health Association of Hong Kong, and articles were written about “counseling services and therapies for people with depression”, or even physical exercise recommendations. The authors highlight that, when analyzing the news, they noticed “the insufficiency of political interventions, institutional support and financial assistance for individuals with depression, which indicates a deficiency at the societal level of coping strategies and which are present in journalistic coverage”.

item.title: Higher education | Academic highlights growth of the sector in Macau
item.description: In “Macau, networks, dialogues and affections – The consolidation of the Portuguese-speaking community of China studies”, academic Pedro Steenhagen argues that Macau is taking great strides to be a bridge at an academic level with Portuguese-speaking countries, despite “still having a long way to go to achieve its goals” The article “Macau, networks, dialogues and affections – The consolidation of the Portuguese-speaking community of China studies”, written by academic and doctoral student Pedro Steenhagen, has just been published in Revista Sinóptica, an editorial project of the Observa China portal. The article highlights the role that the Macao SAR can play in connecting its higher education system with Portuguese-speaking countries, and the growing importance it has had in this area. “The aforementioned efforts in the field of education are not just rhetorical”, he described in the article, noting that “in relatively few decades, the Asian nation has become a true power in the area”. Pedro Steenhagen is based on two world rankings to assess the quality of higher education in the world, namely the World University Rankings 2026 by Times Higher Education (from 2025), which shows how “Macau, a small special administrative region in China, has three ranked universities: University of Macau (145), University of Science and Technology of Macau (251-300) and University of the City of Macau (601-800)”, these data being related to positions occupied in the ranking. “Very interestingly, MSAR universities have experienced tremendous growth; for example, the University of Macau has seen a jump of more than 250 positions in the ranking in the last 10 years”, highlights the author of the article. In his view, these data translate into the fact that Macao SAR “assumes an increasingly relevant leadership role in the area of ​​education and research”. Furthermore, it has “the best university in the Portuguese-speaking world in its territory, is experiencing an intense expansion of the education and research sector and serves as a fundamental axis for the exchange of people and the promotion of knowledge”. Taking the rankings into account, Pedro Steenhagen's article recalls that China “has five [universities] in the top 50 in the world: Tsinghua University (12), Beijing University (13), Fudan University (36), Zhejiang University (39) and Shanghai Jiaotong University (40)”, with the Times Higher Education ranking “showing a total of 97 results for mainland China”. Brazil, as “the largest Portuguese-speaking country on the globe, has a total of 59 results, and its five best universities are: University of São Paulo (201-250), State University of Campinas (351-400), Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (601-800), Universidade Estadual Paulista (601-800) and Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (601-800)”. In the case of Portugal, there are 16 results, with the five best higher education establishments being the University of Coimbra, University of Lisbon, University of Porto, Universidade Nova de Lisboa and ISCTE-Instituto Universitário de Lisboa. Looking at the remaining Portuguese-speaking countries, Pedro Steenhagen highlights how “Mozambique has only one presence in the ranking”, with Eduardo Mondlane University, while “no other Portuguese-speaking country has ranked universities”. A long way Despite the good results, Pedro Steenhagen points out that “the Macao SAR still has a long way to go to achieve all its goals”. However, “its enormous potential as a regional and global protagonist in areas such as technology and innovation, sustainable tourism, creative industry, finance and, particularly, teaching, research and people exchange is already quite clear”. The academic article refers to the “Lusophony component and the unique connection with the PLPs [Portuguese-speaking countries] which adds even more dynamism to its ambitions and to a trajectory that can already be considered incredibly successful since its retrocession”, that is, the transition of the Portuguese administration of Macau to China, in 1999. In the case of the University of Macau (UM), the first to emerge in Macau, and which is now celebrating 45 years of existence, “it has the largest Portuguese department in Asia”, it is highlighted in the article, in addition to having “two research centers: the Research Center for Portuguese-Asian Studies and the Chinese-Portuguese Bilingual Teaching and Training Center”, with “its growing internationalization movement being notable”. Pedro Steenhagen counts the “student exchange programs with more than 10 Brazilian universities”, in addition to the strengthening of “collaboration in teaching and research via international alliances, such as the Association of Portuguese Language Universities, and the establishment of the Center for Judicial and Legal Studies of China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”. The example of the City University of Macau (UCM) is mentioned, where the Institute for Research on Portuguese-Speaking Countries is established, with “unique programs” of master's and doctoral degrees in Studies of Portuguese-Speaking Countries. By establishing partnerships with ISCTE-IUL, UCM is in a “position at the forefront of academic programs and initiatives that go beyond purely linguistic and cultural issues” in connection with Portuguese-speaking countries. There is also the example of a private higher education institution, the University of São José, which “signed [agreements], for example, with the Federal University of Ceará and the Portuguese Catholic University, not only to bring closer relations on a bilateral basis, but also to promote joint projects”. The place of the Government Pedro Steenhagen also refers to the intervention of the Macao SAR Government in connecting with the Portuguese-speaking world, namely the Directorate of Economic and Technological Development Services and the Macau Business Incubation Center for Young People, which have held the Macau Innovation and Entrepreneurship Competition for Technology Companies from Brazil and Portugal since 2021. Of note is the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) in Lisbon and the Macau Houses spread around the world which, “together with international initiatives such as the Meeting of Macanese Communities, contribute not only to the vitality of intellectual exchanges, but also to the cultivation of memory and affective ties between Macau, the diaspora, descendants and Portuguese-speaking communities”. “Associations such as the Association of Brazilian Studies in Macau and the Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau offer substance, in a complementary way to universities and research institutes, for strengthening relationships, developing networks and generating increasingly fruitful dialogues between the parties involved”, it further reads. Pedro Steenhagen is a doctoral candidate in the field of International Politics at the School of International Relations and Public Affairs at Fudan University, and president of the Brazilian Citizens' Council in Shanghai. On the Observa China platform, he is development director and coordinator of the China-Brazil and Lusofonia Relations Center. The platform is a think-tank created in 2020 by “a group of young professionals and students with the mission of creating a network to qualify the debate on China in Portuguese”, reads the website.

item.title: Book | Changes in Portuguese colonial policy at the end of the 19th century
item.description: Defended in 2018, the doctoral thesis by Célia Reis, professor and researcher in contemporary History, has just been published in a book by the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center with the support of the Macau Foundation. “The Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” circulates between Macau, India and Timor and brings “a good contribution to the history of colonial power” Célia Reis, professor and researcher in the area of ​​Contemporary History at Universidade Nova de Lisboa, has just published her doctoral thesis in a book focused on Portuguese colonial power in the East from the end of the 19th century. “Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” is an edition of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM), supported by the Macau Foundation (FM), and arises from the thesis defended in 2018. To HM, Célia Reis argued that this book and its research bring “a good contribution to the history of colonial power”, focusing “on the administrative configurations in the colonies of the East, India, Macau and Timor, in the period between the Ultimatum and the Colonial Act”, published in 1930. “Thousands of documents” were analyzed, namely “formal letters, private letters, reports from departments, drafts, small notes” that demonstrate decisions and the functioning of the Administration in the territories of Portuguese India, Macau and Timor. We speak, according to the author, of “a time of many experiments, in different phases”, and, for Célia Reis, “a gap that existed in Portuguese historiography” was overcome in the sense of a better understanding of the functioning of Portuguese colonial power in these years, and specifically in the territories to the East. In the case of Macau, the book and study contribute “to an administrative history of the period in question”, namely “why it was decided, how it was decided; what problems were posed at an administrative level; how the power of Lisbon was felt and how it was resolved, or how it sought to influence the central power; or who represented it”. The territory is also placed “alongside two other spaces, India and Timor, which are very different, enabling a comparative history, an emphasis on what was common or specific, which, without a doubt, is essential for deeper knowledge”. Célia Reis says she is “very happy with the publication”, for being able to “share the work, investigations and their results, with the public, helping to better understand the history and lived realities”. Historical adjustments The years dedicated to this research show many changes in colonial policy, taking into account that “the colonization movement seen from the last decades of the 19th century was reflected in the way of governing the colonies, giving rise to discussions, studies and adaptations to realities”. Célia Reis further explained that “the existing framework, which had been institutionalized since 1869, was being altered by the creation of new departments, the introduction of new forms of financial control or the change in the status and organization of some colonies, making the administration less homogeneous than was seen in many speeches”. At issue is, in particular, a decree dated December 1, 1869, which proved to be the “true organic charter of the Overseas Provinces”, as stated in the conclusion of the work, without forgetting the Administrative Code of 1842, which “shaped the overseas political bodies for decades”. “Although they lead to a continuous model, in the bodies and their functions, they did not prevent the progressive organization of new configurations or the adaptation of different structures”, we also read. The researcher highlights the occurrence of successive attempts at modernization in legislative and administrative terms, even before the implementation of the First Republic. “Several proposals for modifications were made, with a more modernizing intention, and which had greater emphasis from the last years of the Monarchy, continuing later through the Republic for a more structured change, which ended up being carried out by laws published in 1914 and 1920”. From October 5, 1910, when the Monarchy fell and a republican regime was established, there was “a ministerial change, with the assumption of reference to colonies replacing Ultramar and the autonomy of its ministry”. "In overseas areas, the change of regime was understood as an opportunity for administrative renewal, as can be understood by India's proposal, or by the openness expressed by government bodies to changes in Macau. But the new republican regime remained, in the field of colonial administration, trapped in the circumstances of its beginning, by constitutionalizing it. In fact, in the wide range of changes, colonial issues constituted only one part and parliamentarians did not dedicate themselves sufficiently to them, despite the existence of proposals”, reads the conclusion of the work. In the years of Republicanism, there was “political processing that imposed a framework of parliamentarism, due to some distrust towards the Executive”, and at the level of the colonies “this option led to greater interference by the Senate in the appointment of governors, moving away from what were considered more effective models”. Furthermore, “the rupture also did not take place in the field of participation in Congress, where overseas territories maintained their space in the political game”. "The republican decision also showed a conservative nature in relation to municipal bodies. As it was not possible to carry out a more in-depth study here, it was found that the political vision based on the importance of the municipality, as a space for participation, prevented the deeper changes that were proposed for the internal organization", is mentioned in the conclusion. Barriers and control “Obstacles occurred, such as Sidonism”, followed, with attempts at change being found to be “insufficient”. It should be noted that Sidonism had its origins in a military coup carried out by Sidónio Pais against the republican regime in force in those years, since 1910, and which operated between 1917 and 1918. It was an authoritarian and militaristic regime. According to Célia Reis, it was after the Military Dictatorship of 1926 that “we moved towards greater control” in terms of colonial policy. In general terms, “the regime that began on October 5th was, in short, modernizing in some sense, but its political conceptions and the insertion of colonial issues in the broader space of changes to be carried out in the country allowed the persistence of many previous modes”. “Despite these limitations, the 1914 laws undoubtedly constituted a modernizing step, replacing the existing framework”, concluded Célia Reis, referring to the years of Sidonism as “a rupture in the path that was being followed, with the retreat of colonial capabilities, particularly collegiate bodies and local participation, as well as a decrease in financial autonomy”. This “political trend” experienced in the then metropolis ended up “transplanted overseas”. In terms of documentation used in this investigation, we have the example of the Organic Charters, implemented by Portugal for each colony, and which “arose following the laws of 1914”, analyzing “the various proposals existing in India, Macau and Timor, their implementation process, the essential characteristics of those that belonged to those colonies and their subsequent trajectory”. According to the investigation, “they were the product of the moment in which they took place, inserted in a broader change introduced in Portugal by the Republic, which conditioned their existence, firstly due to the different contributions they had and, later, due to the lack of definition of their situation”. This study analyzes “the way in which central and colonial decisions were operationalized”, having considered “governmental and parliamentary structures”. In the case of colonies, “their organs of power” were studied, where “the governor, interlocutor between metropolis and colony, acted, examining his capabilities and possibility of action, when he was under the authority of a distant ministry, but alongside other supervisory powers, particularly financial, Councils and, in general, under pressure from the various forces of the colony”. In the case of the “competences and composition of the various Councils and means of financial control” they have experienced, in these years, “a change, much more pronounced throughout the various reforms; mainly integrating civil servants”. Furthermore, “the combination of other elements of local society proved to be different, depending on the colonies”. Orders of Lisbon Célia Reis describes that “local deliberations were dependent on superior sanction and remained so beyond the reforms”, and “the practice often circumvented the norm, maintaining uncertainty as a form of action”. Another point to highlight in this study is how the fact that Lisbon made the most important decisions affected life in the colonies. "Although the mandatory sanction remained, the legislation introduced changes, mainly based on the establishment of deadlines. Nevertheless, the metropolitan decision-making capacity remained essential, affecting the life of the colonies. The forms used, persisting what existed or changing the framework, essentially constituted adaptations to the circumstances that occurred, responding both to foreign models and to the needs imposed on Portuguese realities. Politics, in its instability and phases of change, also determined this path", he said.

item.title: Elections | Portugal prepares to choose the next President of the Republic
item.description:
Portugal goes to the vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Republic. Of the 11 candidates, only two have representatives from Macau: Bessa Almeida from the PSD, and Neto Valente from the PS. The former president of the Macau Lawyers Association highlights that António José Seguro “does not join in provocations against China”, while Bessa Almeida considers that Marques Mendes is the right man for the moment
Eleven candidates will vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic, for a five-year term. This is a record number, with only seven having the support of political parties. Running for the position is Luís Marques Mendes, supported by the Social Democratic Party (PSD), and who appointed António Bessa Almeida as his representative in the Macao SAR. Next comes António José Seguro, with the support of the Socialist Party (PS), which has Jorge Neto Valente, president of the Macau Portuguese School Foundation and lawyer, as his representative. They are the only candidates for the Presidency of the Republic who chose figures as representatives of the Macao SAR. The remaining candidates are Henrique Gouveia e Melo, João Cotrim de Figueiredo, Catarina Martins, António Filipe, André Ventura Jorge Pinto, Manuel João Vieira, André Pestana and Humberto Correia. To HM, António Bessa Almeida, PSD activist and explained the reasons for supporting Marques Mendes. “At the time Portugal is going through, the country needs a candidate like Marques Mendes, who has a deep understanding of the different policies”, he began by pointing out. Asked about the type of actions developed in Macau to attract the electorate to vote for Marques Mendes, Bessa Almeida simply mentioned that “the campaign in Macau is totally different from that in Portugal”, and the actions developed involve “what the candidate does in close proximity to the people, passing on information”. For Bessa Almeida, “the electorate in Macau, on the Chinese side, is also made up of Portuguese”, and that “they have been following these elections like any other Portuguese, with confident visions for the future of Portugal”. On January 6th, the president released a note highlighting the importance of Marques Mendes' candidacy, who is currently far from the top spots in the polls. "We have always been concerned with everything related to Portugal and at this moment, at a global level, political changes are sudden and unexpected. That is why we need a visionary president, experienced and thoughtful in guiding the destinies of Portugal and Portuguese people born and living outside the country."
A safe return In Portugal, polls relating to the presidential elections have taken place almost daily, and show a change in the choice of candidates. If initially António José Seguro was somewhat removed from the top positions, a survey carried out by the Universidade Católica Portuguesa for RTP, Antena 1 and the Público newspaper, between the 6th and 9th of January and released this week, shows how Seguro is in a technical tie with André Ventura, Chega's candidate, guaranteeing 23 percent of voting intentions, when Ventura collects 24 percent. João Cotrim de Figueiredo comes in third place, with 19 percent, with the possibility of going to the second round of elections, followed by Marques Mendes and Gouveia e Melo with 14 percent. Another survey, this time for TVI, CNN, TSF and Jornal de Notícias, with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January, shows Seguro with 23.9 percent of voting intentions, followed by Cotrim de Figueiredo with 20.8 percent and Ventura with 20.5 percent. Marques Mendes falls to fifth place, with 13.2 percent. Seguro chose, in the Macao SAR, Jorge Neto Valente as his agent, who did not answer HM's call. In a statement published in the newspapers this Wednesday, the former president of the Macau Lawyers Association declared that Seguro “proposes a vision of the future based on the modernization of the country, the valorization of education and a commitment to innovation”. Referring specifically to Portugal-China relations, Neto Valente highlights that “unlike other candidates, Seguro does not support China's provocations regarding the status of Taiwan, and is also a candidate who “knows Portugal, Europe and the world”. Neto Valente also stated that Seguro “is a decent man”. “He participated in all debates, showed politeness, defended his ideas firmly, was never excessive in his language and, unlike others, did not insult opponents or make malicious insinuations toward them.”
A “consistent route” Paulo Pisco, leader of the Insurance campaign for emigration, reminded HM that the candidate “even expressed the opinion that, given that it was an in-person vote [for the presidential elections], the Government could have done much more, namely complying with what the electoral law for the Presidency of the Republic says, which is the possibility of opening more polling stations”. Seguro also defended, according to Paulo Pisco, “that mobility voting could also have been applied, based on the experience previously carried out in the last elections for the European Parliament”. Paulo Pisco states that António José Seguro has followed a “very consistent, solid and objective path”, which has allowed him to reach the top of the polls. Regarding the emigrated electorate, the deputy highlights that Seguro “has not deviated from the purposes, form and values ​​with which he intends to exercise the Presidency of the Republic”. Furthermore, it is “a guarantor of the stability of the political system and also of democracy”. “This image that the candidate António José Seguro has shown throughout his career has earned him greater receptivity from voters”, highlighted Paulo Pisco. The president does not forget that “Seguro is the candidate who has the most representatives per country in our diaspora”. "There are 18, ten in Europe and eight outside Europe. I believe that this substantiates a very firm commitment from the candidate to the exercise of his functions as President of the Republic, and to the relationship he intends to have with the diaspora", he stressed. Looking at the candidates lower down in the polls, we have many faces from the left. The same survey with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January places Catarina Martins, from Bloco de Esquerda, with 2.5 percent; followed by António Filipe, from PCP, with 1.4 percent, head to head with Jorge Pinto, from Livre, who has 1.3 percent. Manuel João Vieira, visual artist and musician, obtains 1 percent of voting intentions.

item.title: University of Macau | Former teachers recall experiences
item.description: The University of Macau celebrates 45 years and HM invited two former professors to recall their professional experiences at the institution. Brian Hall, from the field of psychology, found “the ideal environment” to start his career. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” and saw Law as a “meeting place” A series of events begins this Sunday to celebrate the 45 years of existence of the University of Macau (UM), including the “Open Day” which takes place at the Lakeside Theater between 11am and 5pm (see secondary text). It was in March 1981, still under the name of the University of East Asia, that UM began to take its first steps in local higher education, namely in the teaching of Law in the Portuguese language. It was the first time that Macau had its own university, providing a higher education offering for residents, who no longer only had the opportunity to pursue studies abroad, such as Portugal, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong or Australia. To commemorate the anniversary, HM invited two former professors of the institution, from two different academic areas, to talk about their experience at UM. Vera Lúcia Raposo, who taught at the Faculty of Law from January 2014, remembers feeling “a shock”. "The classes were entirely in English, and I had never taught a complete course in that language, the pressure to publish in indexed journals was absolute and the evaluation system was periodic, demanding and relentless. Nothing there resembled the regime I was used to, where the simple passage of time often seemed to guarantee the natural advancement of an academic career", she said. However, adaptation arrived and ended up following “the rules” to this day, namely at NOVA School of Law. “At the time, however, these requirements were still profoundly strange in Portugal, and they continue to be so, in many contexts, even today”, he says. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” at UM, as “the demanding scientific production goals and interdisciplinary research contributed to defining the type of academic I am today”. “I owe UM more than a professional transition, but a transformation”, he assures. A cultural melting pot The former professor at the UM Faculty of Law also remembers arriving in a territory that was “a space of true cultural amalgamation”, with the institution being an example of this. "Working side by side with colleagues of different nationalities and cultures was a rare privilege. In particular, the intellectual coexistence between Chinese, Macanese and Portuguese colleagues, in the study and teaching of Macau Law, offered me an absolutely unique way of thinking about Law: less self-centered, more dialoguing, more aware of its cultural and historical contingency", highlighted Vera Lúcia Raposo. Brian Hall, who taught at the Faculty of Social Sciences and coordinated the “Global and Community Mental Health Research Group”, highlights the possibility of doing pioneering work in the area of ​​mental health. "UM gave me the opportunity to develop unique and never-before-taught courses in Global Mental Health and Global Health. They were the first courses of their kind in Macau and at the university", recalled Brian Hall, who is now linked to New York University Shanghai. “I was grateful to have some really great students who were interested in topics like migration, global and digital mental health, and I really enjoyed mentoring them in and out of the classroom.” The first prizes The academic also highlights the fact that he “regularly published research articles with undergraduate and postgraduate students, taking them to international research conferences, where they won awards”. “We were among the first at the university to achieve these excellent results and I am eternally grateful to UM for providing me with all these opportunities”, he confessed. Brian Hall also added that he joined UM “in a period of ambitious transition and growth to become a research university”, providing “an ideal environment to launch a career”. When he was at UM, Brian Hall received, in 2020, an award for his work, the “Excellence in Advising Award” from the Center for Global Health at Johns Hopkins University, from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. "The university rewarded me for my excellent research performance by granting me permission to apply for an early promotion to associate professor, which I was granted just four years after joining the university. UM served as a springboard to build a regional and international career," he said. Book of Genesis The need to create a university in Macau arose from the desire to develop the territory, especially taking into account the signing of the Joint Declaration between Portugal and China in 1987. The former Governor of Macau Garcia Leandro recalled the first moments of the creation of the future university in the book “Macau in the Years of the Portuguese Revolution 1974-1979”, which reads that the initial budget was 40 million patacas for construction “on land on the island of Taipa, with a modern architectural project”. The institution should have capacity for “a population of two thousand students in four years, at a rate of 500 per year”, with “the leadership of the various course chairs guaranteed by a dean professor with a doctorate from the University of Oxford and by several university professors from Matteo Ricci, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and also from the USA”, it is described. The first contract to train the teaching team and pedagogical content was signed in February 1979 with the Matteo Ricci group. “I believe it was another good service provided to the population”, wrote the former Governor. In 1991, the institution changed its name to what it currently has. According to data from the 2024 annual report, the latest available, UM has 52,146 graduated students, and in the first semester of the 2024/2025 academic year, 15,147 students attended the university, from all educational levels. Highlight is the greater number of students from abroad, 9,328, compared to 5,819 local students. Open day in Hengqin Despite having been formally created in March, UM begins to celebrate 45 years of existence this Sunday with an Open Day. According to a statement from the educational institution, between 11 am and 5 pm the public will be able to visit the Lakeside Theater, where the first ceremony takes place, and then other areas of the campus in Hengqin, namely the main campus and the UM Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Zhuhai, in the Youth Entrepreneurship Valley in Hengqin. This route also includes the possibility of visiting, for the first time, the Transitional Research and Education Site at Yuxin Tower, in the Cooperation Zone. “Through a wide range of on-site activities and live online broadcasts, the event will showcase UM’s latest developments and achievements in teaching, research and community service”, highlights the same note, which recalls how UM was the first higher education institution in Macau to “extend teaching and research activities to the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin”. That day there will also be “approximately 250 activities on the main campus throughout the day, including admissions lectures, academic and research activities and interactive games”. "Visitors interested in academic subjects can attend engaging lectures on science and other disciplines, while sports enthusiasts can explore UM's sports facilities. Families can also participate in interactive games at stands, scientific experiments, workshops and knowledge challenges organized by various faculties, residences and laboratories", it is revealed. On Open Day there will also be discounts in the restaurant area.

item.title: Church | Pope closes 2025 with criticism of consumerism and xenophobia
item.description: Pope Leo The speech served to close the Jubilee - a Holy Year that usually takes place every 25 years, proclaimed by the Pope as a special time of forgiveness, reconciliation and spiritual renewal -, which brought around 33 million pilgrims to Rome and included a historic transition from one American pontiff to another. In the presence of cardinals and diplomats from all over the world, Leo This situation had only occurred once, in 1700. Yesterday's ceremony, at the beginning of the mass celebrating the feast of the Epiphany (when the three Magi offered gifts to the newborn Jesus) ended a dizzying year of special audiences, masses and meetings that dominated Leo XIV's first months as pontiff and put his own agenda on hold. To signal that his pontificate can now begin in earnest, the Pope summoned cardinals from around the world to the Vatican, for meetings on Wednesday and Thursday that aim to debate the governance of the Catholic Church, with its 1.4 billion faithful. To reflect In yesterday's homily, Leo XIV said that the jubilee year invited all Christians to reflect on the biblical teachings of welcoming strangers and resisting the “flattery and seduction of those who hold power”. “Around us, a distorted economy tries to profit from everything”, he criticized, adding that he hopes that this year it will be possible to recognize “a pilgrim in the visitor, a seeker abroad, a neighbor in the stranger and a traveling companion in someone who is different”. The Holy Years usually include large public works projects, as was the case with the construction of the Sistine Chapel (commissioned by Pope Sixtus IV for the Jubilee of 1475) and the large Vatican garage, where popemobiles and other vehicles are parked (commissioned by John Paul II for the Jubilee of 2000). Some works were controversial, such as the construction of Via della Conciliazione, in 1950, which leads to St. Peter's Square and which involved the demolition of an entire neighborhood. Leo XIV also announced that the next Jubilee will be in 2033, to commemorate the 2000th anniversary of what the Scriptures indicate as the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ, in 33 AD.

item.title: Medals | Ho Iat Seng, Kou Hoi In and Raimundo do Rosário distinguished
item.description: The list of winners is marked by the award of two Medals of Honor of the Great Lotus, the highest distinction in the Macao SAR, to Ho Iat Seng and Kou Hoi In. All the individuals awarded served in the Government or in the Legislative Assembly The former Chief Executive, Ho Iat Seng, and the former president of the Legislative Assembly, Kou Hoi In, will be awarded the Great Lotus Medal of Honor, the Macao SAR's highest distinction. The list of the Executive's distinctions for 2025 was announced on December 31st, through a statement from the Social Communication Office, and the award ceremony is scheduled for January 30th, at the Macau Cultural Center. The main distinctions awarded by Sam Hou Fai were to former rulers, with Macanese and former Secretary for Transport and Public Works Raimundo do Rosário being awarded the Golden Lotus Medal of Honor. This distinction will also be awarded to Ho Veng On, former Commissioner of Audit, and Vong Man Chong, former director-general of the Customs Service. Medals of honor aim to distinguish individuals or entities that have contributed to the image and good name of the Macao SAR. After the list of medals was announced, Ho Iat Seng considered the title “a profound honor”. The former Government leader also stated, in a statement, that he “has always maintained a deep affection for Macau” and that over the years he has “dedicated” himself to “serving the nation and Macau”. The former Chief Executive praised the results of his governance and considered that they depended “not only on the dedication and hard work of the government action team and all Public Administration employees, but also on the strong support and joint efforts of the community and all residents”. “This honor is a collective victory, which demonstrates the commitment of the entire society to drive greater and better development for the Macao SAR,” he stated. The text awarding the Great Lotus Medal of Honor to Ho Iat Seng highlights the period in which the former ruler had to deal with the Covid-19 pandemic. “During his term as the fifth Chief Executive, he united the Macao SAR Government and all social sectors, successfully overcame the severe challenges and difficulties of the Covid-19 pandemic and made every effort to promote post-pandemic economic recovery and social development”, it was stated. In addition to being Chief Executive, Ho Iat Seng, a businessman by profession, was president of the Legislative Assembly, member of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress and member of the Executive Council. This is the third time that Ho Iat Seng will be honored, after in 2001 having received the Medal of Industrial and Commercial Merit and in 2009 having been distinguished with the Golden Lotus Medal of Honor. Another Lotus Another distinguished businessman and former president of the Legislative Assembly is Kou Hoi In, notable for his activity as a member of the National People's Congress, the main legislative body of the People's Republic of China, and for more than 34 years as a deputy of the Legislative Assembly. “In legislation work, supervision of government action and formulation of public policies, it has always defended the principles of carrying out functions in accordance with the law, in a rational and pragmatic manner, actively promoted the improvement of regimes and the construction of the rule of law and committed itself to safeguarding the rights and interests of residents and promoting social stability and long-term development”, it was considered. “During his term as President of the Legislative Assembly of Macau from 2019 to 2025, he focused his efforts on improving the efficiency of parliamentary functioning, promoting positive interaction between the Executive Branch and the Legislative Branch, and made important contributions to strengthening the construction of the Rule of Law, promoting social harmony and improving the population's well-being policies”, it was added. After leaving the Chamber, Kou was appointed to serve as chairman of the Board of Directors of TDM, he is also vice-president of the Board of Directors and general manager of the China Special Products and Productions Company and vice-president of the Macau Commercial Association. In the past, the previous president of AL had been awarded the Industrial and Commercial Merit Medal in 2007 and the Silver Lotus Medal of Honor in 2016. In Portuguese Raimundo do Rosário, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, between 2014 and 2024, is the only representative of the Macanese community in the 2025 distinctions, taking into account the distinguished individuals and associations. In the text about the former ruler, several positions held in public and private institutions are indicated. “He joined the Civil Service in 1979 and worked until 1990 successively as a senior technician, head of department, deputy director and director of the Land, Public Works and Transport Services”, it can be read. His CV also states that he was a member of the Portuguese delegation of the Portuguese-Chinese Land Group, deputy of the Board of Directors of CAM-Sociedade of Macau International Airport and head of the Macau Economic and Commercial Delegation, in Lisbon, also having charge of the Economic and Commercial Delegations to the European Union, in Brussels and the World Trade Organization, in Geneva. Raimundo was also a member of the Drafting Committee of the Basic Law and the Preparatory Committee for the Establishment of the Special Administrative Region of Macau, deputy and member of the Supervisory Board of Banco Comercial de Macau. In terms of medals of honor, the Macau Banks Association will be awarded the Silver Lotus, due to its “fundamental role in promoting sector collaboration and the solid development of the industry”. Medals of Merit In terms of the professional merit medal this year, only one distinction appears, for Chan Iok Lin, who has been a member of the Office of the President of the Court of Final Instance since 2000, having become head in 2016. “He has always demonstrated a rigorous and dedicated attitude in carrying out his duties, possessing excellent leadership and organizational skills, as well as a high level of professionalism and a spirit of dedication”, he was justified. In the industrial and commercial area, the distinctions went to the state-owned company Companhia de Logística Nam Kwong, from the Nam Kwong group, for its contributions to the diversification of the economy and to businesswoman Amber Li Jiaming, who is president of the HN Group and member of the 14th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), vice-president of the CPPCC Foreign Affairs Commission and member of the Council for the Economic Development of Macau. At a tourist level, the only distinction was given to the House of Dancing Water Show Team, from Melco Resorts & Entertainment. The show was suspended during the pandemic, but returned after the end of border restrictions imposed during the years of combating Covid-19. In terms of education, the Macau University of Science and Technology, Keang Peng School and Kao Yip School were distinguished. In culture, the distinctions went to the Chinese Opera Association of Maritime and Land Residents of Barra de Macau, deputy Lam Fat Iam and artist Chan Iu Pui, who draws caricatures for the newspaper Ou Mun. Finally, an Altruistic Merit Medal will be awarded to the China International Emergency Medical Team (SAR) and Sports Merit medals to the MSAR Karate Team that participated in the National Games. Athlete Zhu Yuling, who defended the colors of Interior until 2024, when she moved to Macau, will also be honored. The athlete went on to represent the Macao SAR under professional staff promotion programs and won the women's singles title in the WTT of United States Smash Table Tennis, the first athlete from Macau to achieve this feat. Currently, she is a professor at Tianjin University. item.title: Elections | Portuguese in Macau ask for attention from those far away
item.description: Outside the historic building of the Consulate General of Portugal in Macau, Portuguese people who chose to vote on Saturday celebrate the democratic moment and demand “more care” for those who live far away. Several voters again suggested the implementation of electronic voting. It was a “somewhat confusing - as the world is at the moment -” presidential campaign, but one that Cristina Osswald made a point of following. And on this sunny, winter day in Macau, the Portuguese celebrate the possibility of choice. "Whenever possible I would listen to interviews, debates and presentations of the candidates. But it seemed to me that, perhaps, there is this issue of a dispersion of votes, which is part of democracy, isn't it? And especially when you live in a regime that is not democratic, you clearly appreciate democracy more", the professor at the Macau Polytechnic University tells Lusa after voting. But the path that a Macau voter takes until the moment of voting, highlights Osswald, is not ideal. Having lived outside of Portugal for six years, the teacher notes that “procedures have improved”, although “they remain below expectations”. “The world is increasingly global, I see no reason why there should not be electronic voting”, considers the teacher, who, before Macau, passed through Florence, where to vote she had to go to Milan. “We can go to the bank [‘online’], to the finance department, and not being able to vote ‘online’ seems like something that doesn’t make much sense. I think that would be where there should also be greater investment. For example, here, people with little mobility cannot come and vote”, she declares. Cristina Osswald looks at the staircase that leads to the consulate, where at that moment, elderly people are climbing the steps with difficulty – despite the fact that, at the back of the building, there is another door with access to an elevator. "It is democracy that is losing. In times that are complicated and, I would say, almost dramatic, I think it would be an extremely simple thing to be able to vote online", continues the professor, also referring to the "little information" in Macau about the procedures leading up to the election. “I know a lot of people here in Macau, especially older people, who don't come to vote, because it wasn't announced that we had to register beforehand”, he notes. Ancient pretension Electronic choice has been a long-standing demand of the Council of Portuguese Communities, the Government's advisory body for policies relating to emigration and Portuguese communities abroad. Rui Marcelo, president of the Regional Council of the Portuguese Communities of Asia and Oceania, told Lusa last year that the topic “was addressed several times and with several governments”. Félix Teixeira, a retired laboratory technician who has lived in Macau for 30 years, argues that online voting could serve especially regions where “travel is difficult”. “Macau is small, it doesn’t matter here.” And what expectations do you have from the presidential elections? For the former employee of the Institute for Municipal Affairs, the multiplicity of faces on the bulletins is a good omen: “More voices are heard”, he says. And for emigrants, he emphasizes, being here today means getting closer to home: “If you are not in direct contact with the country, you are outside the entire circuit, politics and the social sphere”, he adds. Feel from a distance According to the consulate, there are more than 150 thousand Portuguese passport holders among residents of Macau and Hong Kong. However, when registered to vote, the number is almost three times lower: 57,748, according to data provided to Lusa by the diplomatic representation. From the top of the stairs of the historic consulate building – formerly Hospital de São Rafael, founded in 1569 – the Macanese couple Francisco Xavier Leong and Alina da Luz ask for more attention from those abroad. “We hope that the new president will be more careful with foreign citizens, not just from Portugal”, says Leong. “We vote because we are Portuguese and, as good citizens, it is our duty”, adds the woman. For the couple, who live nearby, voting in person is simpler. Francisco Leong even admits “more difficulty” with the electronic option. "Fortunately, in Portugal we have always had great confidence in the electoral results. There are many people who have doubts about electronic voting, but I think that if it is conducted well, it is a good option", says, in turn, José Paulo Esperança. To Lusa, the Finance professor at the City University of Macau says he expects high participation in the ballot, because “there are concerns for Portuguese democracy” and “worrying candidates”. "Portugal – and the world – is experiencing developments that worry me. Because there is an increasing rise of the extreme right and phenomena that are very worrying", he states. In the 2021 presidential elections, 1,479 people voted in Macau, or 2.1 percent of the total registered (70,134). Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa won in this Chinese region with 64.62 percent of the votes, followed by Ana Gomes (14.45 percent) and André Ventura (8.03 percent).

item.title: Health | Meeting brings together authorities from Macau, Hong Kong and Mainland China
item.description: Last Thursday, the MSAR hosted the 20th Joint Meeting of the Health Administration Summits of Mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, where the training of qualified staff, community health and the development of intelligent healthcare were discussed. The meeting brought together more than 70 senior health administration officials and medical experts from the three territories also with the objectives of “deepening the exchange, sharing of experiences and discussion on the future direction of cooperation”, the Health Services indicated on Friday. The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, highlighted that the Macao SAR Government will implement the strategy of giving “health priority” included in the “National Fifteenth Five-Year Plan” and execute the “Action Plan for Healthy Macau”, integrating physical and mental health elements into public policies. The leader also highlighted the launch of the “Well-being and Health Station” program, to take advantage of health resources in community neighborhoods. Complying with the national “Year of Weight Management” initiative, O Lam stated that “community health self-examination stations will be increased” and residents will be encouraged to “be ‘first responsible’ for their own health”.

item.title: Government | Sam Hou Fai talks about “good start” to his term
item.description: The Chief Executive considers that the Government has made “a good start”. It was in this way that Sam Hou Fai took stock of the first year of governance, in a meeting with 70 members of the Administration to reiterate the need for rulers to “implement the spirit” of Xi Jinping's speeches. According to the official version of the meeting, released by the Social Communication Office, Sam Hou Fai “stated that the work of the first year of this government took place in a stable, successive and peaceful manner, with reforms, innovations, advances and results”, which he considered to be “a good start”. The Chief Executive praised public services for having as a priority “the fundamental interests of the Country and the integral interests of Macau” which are seen as “the starting point for installing a global mentality that firmly guarantees the sovereignty, national security and development interests of the Country, and ensures the stable and harmonious situation of Macau”. Secondly, Sam highlighted the efforts of employees to strengthen “interdepartmental collaboration and cooperation in order to increase executive efficiency” and highlighted the “precise” implementation of government actions. Sam Hou Fai also referred to “the importance of being more aware of shortcomings” and the need for shortcomings “to be checked as the work is carried out, in order to analyze existing problems and make appropriate improvements”. Follow the spirit Regarding the current year, Sam Hou Fai promised that he will continue “to fully implement the spirit of President Xi Jinping's speeches to plan future work”. The Government leader also called for a single-minded Government, which maximizes the “central role of the Chief Executive”. “All guardianships and services must unify the same thinking, make every effort and collaborate proactively, with a high sense of responsibility and mission and thus create an enormous force to work and advance together, so that, together, they complete this priority task of the Macao SAR government for this year”, he stated. “At the same time, it must urge and improve the predominance of executive power, maximizing the central role of the Chief Executive and the Macao SAR government in the governance system,” he added. And in this organization centralized around the Chief of Executive, the Legislative Assembly is also included: “The Secretary for Administration and Justice must effectively fulfill her duties and responsibilities, reinforcing coordination and cooperation to ensure that the Macao SAR government assumes its central governance functions with professionalism and pragmatism, in order to create a governance structure with an interconnection between the upper and lower levels and a synergy of cooperation between services, and to promote positive interaction between the executive powers and legislative bodies that cooperate, support and promote reciprocally, at an institutional, political and operational level”, he said.

item.title: Finance | Foreign Exchange Reserves reached 245.6 billion
item.description: Macau's foreign exchange reserves stood at 245.6 billion patacas, equivalent to 30.64 billion US dollars, at the end of December, according to the most recent information from the Macau Monetary Authority (AMCM). The numbers were released yesterday and are part of preliminary estimates. The value of 245.6 billion patacas represents an increase of 2 percent compared to the corrected data from the previous month, which reached 240.8 billion patacas, or 30.05 billion US dollars. At the end of December 2025, the Macao SAR's foreign exchange reserves corresponded to around 11 times monetary circulation, or 91.8 percent of the M2 monetary aggregate in patacas, according to data from the end of November 2025. The effective exchange rate of the Macau pataca, weighted by its trade shares, was 101.1 in December 2025, recording decreases of 0.81 points and 5.47 points, compared to the data recorded in the previous month and those reported to December 2024. This variation means that the pataca fell against the currencies of Macau's main trading partners.

item.title: Industrial Park | DSEDT wants the project to follow local reality
item.description: The Economic and Technological Development Services Department (DSEDT) says it is working on the creation of the Macau Science and Technology Research and Development Industrial Park, hoping that this project “accompanies the real needs of Macau's development”. In response to the written question from deputy Ngan Iek Hang, the DSEDT considers that this is “an important project to boost the development of Macau's technological industry”, with a public consultation having been held between 27 November and 26 December 2025. Furthermore, an interdepartmental working group was created “for the purposes of coordination and consultation” of the project, with “in-depth studies and analyses” being commissioned from a “professional study team”. Everything so that the authorities understand “the positioning, construction plan and complementary facilities of the Park”. Another study was also commissioned from a “research team” to “develop planning for the development of Macau’s technological industry, taking international and regional successful experiences as a reference”.

item.title: Health | Government wants permanent link with national commission
item.description:
The Chief Executive met with leaders of the National Health Commission and defended the creation of a permanent collaboration mechanism with the national entity. Professional training and the promotion of big health as one of Macau's core industries were some of the topics discussed
The Chief Executive met on Wednesday with the director and secretary of the Party Leadership Group of the National Health Commission, Lei Haichao, with the agenda marked by the desire to deepen cooperation, promote the development of the big health industry, and the integrated training of qualified personnel. Sam Hou Fai defended the creation of a permanent collaboration mechanism between the Macao SAR Government and the National Health Commission to “further develop the healthcare and big health industry, both in Mainland China and in Macau”, a sector characterized as core to the territory's economy. The connection between business and health was one of the guiding threads of the meeting, with Sam Hou Fai highlighting the need to “promote adequate diversification of the economy and fully take advantage of Macau's regional and political advantages”. Another aspect that the leader of the Macau Government would like to see developed with the national commission is the strengthening of prevention and control of communicable diseases, although no details have been given on the subject.
Three-way conversations The “cultivation” of qualified interdisciplinary staff in the health sector was another objective that Sam Hou Fai emphasized, stating “he hopes that the commission will provide strong support to Macau so that the city can fully take advantage of its role as a Sino-Lusophone platform”. The objective will be to raise the level of professionalism of the medical and nursing team through the training of staff “capable of serving international organizations”. Before the director of the Islands Health Care Complex, Liu Zhengyin, who also participated in the meeting, the Chief Executive highlighted the symbolism that the unit represents for the “marking cooperation project between the Macao SAR and Mainland China in the field of health, under the principle of ‘one country, two systems’”. The leaders of the National Health Commission traveled to Macau to participate in the 20th Joint Meeting of the Health Administration Summits of Mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau. Also present at the meeting were the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, the head of the Chief Executive's Office, Chan Kak, the director of Health Services, Alvis Lo, as well as several directors of entities in Mainland China.

item.title: Communities | Rui Marcelo promises to listen to Portuguese people “with humility”
item.description: The president of the Regional Council of Asia and Oceania of the Council of Portuguese Communities, Rui Marcelo, promises to “listen with humility” to the population throughout the new year. The promise was left in a message with a “renewed commitment” for the new year, disseminated through social media. "Our first obligation is to listen. We will strengthen the channels of dialogue, ensuring that all voices from our diverse community feel truly represented", it was promised. “The strength of our global Lusophone community has never resided in monologue, but in dialogue; not in forced unanimity, but in unity built on respect and shared purpose”, reinforced Marcelo. "May 2026 be the year in which, side by side, we demonstrate that what unites us – a glorious heritage and a future of unlimited potential – is infinitely stronger than anything that seeks to divide us. May this new cycle bring us the serenity for constructive dialogue, the courage to make the right choices and the tireless strength to serve", he added. Rui Marcelo also promised to “act with transparency” pointing out that “each initiative, each project of the Asia and Oceania Regional Council will be conducted with absolute clarity”. “Our action will be measurable, oriented towards tangible results that strengthen cultural, economic and social ties in the regions we represent”, he added.

item.title: This country is not for pregnant women
item.description: Young women in Portugal live in a dilemma. Those who study and complete a higher education course. Those who work in the most diverse professions, namely cleaning city streets, as informal caregivers, restaurant employees, in factories, digital platform coordinators, nurses, lawyers, Uber drivers, store employees, doctors, architects and so many, many professions that we can imagine. And the dilemma is your future. When they finish a course or start working, a large number of young people aged 25, 30 and even 35 continue to live in their parents' homes because their monthly income is not enough to buy or rent a house. Others, upon gaining independence and committing to a relationship or marriage, then come face to face with reality. The dream of having children. Getting pregnant and having a child seems, at first glance, normal. But it's not. Nowadays in Portugal we know that the birth rate has decreased a lot and that the country already has a greater number of old people than young people. As for the birth rate, several factors contribute to the fact that young women and even women over 40, even those committed to a partner or husband, are faced with increasingly expensive homes, with a salary that does not even allow them to rent a house, if they actually live in Lisbon, Porto, Coimbra or Évora. Young women start to calculate their lives and immediately think how it will be possible to get pregnant if they remain in their parents' homes, some with their partner, how is it possible to rent a house to be able to have a child if the national minimum wage is one of the lowest in Europe, how can they buy a house on installments if not even their parents are available to be guarantors, how are they going to get pregnant if they then spend months in hospital appointments waiting for hours and hours and missing work, how can they get pregnant if they begin to panic when they hear the news that a pregnant woman has given birth at home without medical support, in an ambulance, in her husband's private car or even on the street, how can they think about having children if the same news they hear conveys a feeling of pain and bitterness because they learn that most Pediatrics and Gynecology - Obstetrics emergencies are closed and that pregnant women are transported by ambulance a distance of 200 and 300 kilometers walking from hospital to hospital to find an open emergency room. Some will say that the Government has improved INEM's customer service and that pregnant women can know what emergency services are available. Yes, available more than 100 kilometers away. And let's not talk about INEM. If we go that way, there aren't even ambulances and stretchers available to help the population. Recently, we witnessed the death of three Portuguese people due to a lack of assistance from INEM. The fact was so serious that the volunteer firefighters decided to make their ambulances available to INEM. A measure that deserves the best praise for this agreement between firefighters and INEM, which immediately saved the lives of several patients. But, of course, the “demon” had to appear. Continuously, a Civil Protection, which has served to make “pots” available to friends of those in power, soon came to the public, leaving us with our mouths open. Civil Protection had the nerve to maintain a position contrary to the agreement between volunteer firefighters and INEM. Obviously the firefighters ordered Civil Protection to dig potatoes and take a walk to Berlengas… In such a scenario, how can a young woman think about getting pregnant without fear, without panic, without anxiety? It cannot, and so we reach the crucial point: the birth rate in Portugal has to decrease and there are increasingly fewer pregnant women. Conclusion: this country is not for pregnant women.

item.title: After the robbed house, you lock the door
item.description: There is an old Chinese saying that says, “It is not too late to fix the fence after the sheep have run away”, which has the same meaning as our proverb “After the house is robbed, you lock the door”. Only after we have been left without our assets do we realize that we have to take measures that can prevent future losses, but that do not allow us to recover what was lost. The fire at Wang Fuk Court, a large housing complex in Hong Kong's Tai Po district, destroyed many lives and many homes. The Hong Kong Government immediately provided assistance to the victims, quickly inspected the nets covering the scaffolding of all buildings undergoing maintenance in the city and created an Independent Committee to investigate the causes of the fire at Wang Fuk Court. The Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) and the Police also acted promptly, arresting and charging those responsible for the fire. The measures that were taken after the accident demonstrate the authorities' great concern about what happened. However, if the various problems caused by maintenance work had been detected earlier, would the fire have been avoided? While putting out fires is necessary, preventing them is more important. As a neighbor of Hong Kong, Macau, although it did not suffer any devastating fires in 2025, has many aspects that need to be improved. The stability and development of a society are inseparable from its political and economic systems. After the change of the Macao SAR Chief Executive in 2024, the Legislative Assembly election in 2025 witnessed the disqualification of candidates for the second time, along with the reshuffle of key leaders. According to the amendment to the Law “Electoral Assembly for the Legislative Assembly of the Macau Special Administrative Region”, “the decision of the CAEAL that a candidate does not have the capacity to be a candidate……, there is no room for complaint or legal appeal”, the disqualified candidates were not given the reasons for being considered that “they do not defend the Basic Law or that they are not faithful to the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China”. Furthermore, the fact that Cheong Weng Chon went from Secretary for Administration and Justice to President of the VIII Legislative Assembly set a precedent for this Assembly. These actions taken by the Macao SAR Government established an absolute precedent for the predominance of executive power established by the Basic Law for the coming years. The absence of dissenting voices and close coordination between the executive and legislative branches have the advantage of unifying thought and action, which leads to a more fluid and efficient implementation of adopted policies and measures. However, it is worrying that when problems arise during the implementation process, there are no voices of opposition. And improving efficiency does not guarantee good results. We should not wait for problems to solve them, on the contrary, we should understand the causes of problems before they occur. After seeing the report on the fire in Hong Kong, it becomes obvious that the tragedy could have been avoided. The challenges facing the diversification of Macau's economy are more complex than the difficulties it faced during the transformation that occurred in the early days after the return to Chinese sovereignty. If we just look at the increase in the number of tourists, at the GNI per capita at 572,614 patacas and the GDP per capita at 579,533 patacas, in 2024, we would think that Macau's economy should be flourishing, with no stores closed, with residents enjoying high incomes and restaurants packed with customers. Is this really the case? Those responsible for the economy know the truth, and citizens can see reality clearly. The closure of satellite casinos was predictable, while the creation of shopping districts and open-air cafes are only recent developments. Consumer trends such as cross-border shopping and online shopping are gaining great popularity, although the Government has taken emergency measures such as the “Grand prize for consumption in community areas” and “Discounts for eating at restaurants in celebration of Macau’s Return to the Motherland”. But what comes next? When prior planning falls far short of the course of events, and when all criticism is silenced, what remains is deep regret. A good shepherd does not allow a single sheep to go astray and the key to preventing them from getting lost is the shepherd.

item.title: Portugal and the 2026 Presidential Scenario
item.description: “When societies feel unheard, they do not fall silent – ​​they change the way they speak.” – Zygmunt Bauman On January 18th, Portugal finds itself facing one of the most significant moments in its recent democratic history. Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa's presidential cycle, which began in 2016 and concluded this year, ends with the constitutional impossibility of re-candidacy, opening space for a plural and unprecedented dispute. The presidential election, scheduled for January 18th, with a possible second round scheduled for February 8th, is not just a routine democratic exercise; It is a test of the country's institutional maturity, the capacity for renewal of political elites and the resilience of Portuguese society in the face of global challenges. The Portuguese semi-presidential system, enshrined in the 1976 Constitution, assigns moderating functions to the President of the Republic, but with relevant powers in times of crisis, such as the dissolution of the Assembly of the Republic or the appointment of the Prime Minister. Since the Revolution of April 25, 1974, all presidents have served two consecutive terms, and the inability of Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa to run again opens up space for an original competition. The Portuguese presidency has been marked by figures that symbolize different phases of democracy with Ramalho Eanes as the military founder of post-revolutionary stability, Mário Soares as a Europeanist and defender of integration, Jorge Sampaio as a social moderator, Cavaco Silva as a liberal economist and Marcelo as an empathetic communicator. The 2026 succession is part of this historical line, but with its own characteristics, such as the absence of an incumbent, party fragmentation and the emergence of new political actors. Among the candidates, figures from different political and social backgrounds stand out. Luís Marques Mendes, for the PSD, represents institutional continuity and the connection to the traditional center-right. António José Seguro, for the PS, is committed to social cohesion and defending the values ​​of April. Henrique Gouveia e Melo, independent, emerges as a candidate with strong popular appeal and an image of technical competence, as a result of his leadership in the vaccination campaign against COVID-19. André Ventura, for Chega, bets on a security and nationalist discourse, seeking to capitalize on social discontent. João Cotrim de Figueiredo, for the Liberal Initiative, defends the reduction of the weight of the State and economic liberalization. Catarina Martins, for Bloco de Esquerda, focuses on social justice and human rights. This plurality reflects a more diverse but also more polarized society. Polls suggest that no candidate is expected to achieve an absolute majority in the first round, making a second round likely between two candidates from different blocs. Portugal enters 2026 with an economy marked by post-pandemic recovery, but also by structural challenges, such as low productivity, demographic aging and energy dependence. Tourism continues to be the economic engine, but faces sustainability pressures and the need for diversification. The digital and ecological transition is imperative, requiring consistent public policies and investment in innovation. Socially, the country is experiencing tensions between the valorization of public services and fiscal pressure, between European integration and the resurgence of nationalist discourses. The aging of the population poses challenges to the sustainability of social security and intergenerational cohesion. Social inequality, although mitigated by redistributive policies, remains a central concern. The presidency, although it does not hold executive powers, can play a symbolic and mobilizing role, influencing agendas and promoting consensus. Portuguese culture, deeply rooted in historical memory and Portuguese-speaking projection, plays a central role in international affirmation. The presidency symbolizes the continuity of republican and democratic values, with the President seen as the guarantor of stability and national unity. The plurality of candidates reflects different views on national identity, from the defense of April to security rhetoric, from social empathy to institutional technocracy. Portuguese cultural diversity, marked by the coexistence of local traditions and openness to the world, finds in the presidency a space of symbolic representation. The 2026 election will also be a moment of identity affirmation, in which values ​​such as solidarity, freedom and European belonging are debated. Portugal remains an active member of the European Union, participating in debates on economic integration, energy transition and common defense. The 2026 presidency will be crucial to ensuring diplomatic stability in a global context of geopolitical tensions. The choice of a president with a conciliatory or more interventionist profile could influence the external perception of the country.
